newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Extradited drug lord Perafan is flown to U.S..
newsitem.headline: Extradited drug lord Perafan is flown to U.S..

text.p: Suspected Colombian drug lord Justo Pastor Perafan left Venezuela on Friday for the United States to face drug trafficking and possession charges in New York.
The transfer became possible after Venezuela's Supreme Court decided on Thursday to extradite him.

Perafan, captured near the Colombian border in April, was flown from Caracas's Francisco de Miranda military airport in a light plane at 2:30 p.m. local time (1830 GMT), escorted by members of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration.
Unofficial sources said he would stop first at the U.S. military base at Guantanamo, Cuba, before flying to New York.

Colombia also lodged an extradition request for Perafan. But many legal experts, and Colombia's police chief, Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano, said he would face a tougher sentence in the U.S where he is wanted on eight charges in the New York state court.
Believed to possesss a personal fortune of $12 billion, Perafan is said to be the last Colombian drug lord not in jail or dead.
